c74object.name: fl.multitaper~
c74object.digest: Calculates a multitaper power (or amplitude) spectrum from a real input
c74object.description: The spectrum is calculated using the sine tapers. All FFTs use a power of two size, with zero-padding applied at the input if necessary. Output frames will be (N / 2) + 1 in length where N is the FFT size used. The number of tapers and their weighting are both controllable.

entry.name: /max_length [instantiation int]
entry.description: Sets the maximum input length (and associated internal FFT size).

entry.name: /num_tapers [int]
entry.description: Sets the number of tapers to use.

entry.name: /normalise [bool]
entry.description: Sets normalisation on or off (such that the energy of a full-scale sine wave is 1).

entry.name: /output [enum]
entry.description:
Sets whether to output values in terms of power or amplitude.
[0] - power[1] - amplitude

entry.name: /weighting [enum]
entry.description:
Sets the weighting of the tapers:
[0] - uniform - all tapers are weighted equally.[1] - linear - tapers are weighted linearly in a decreasing manner.[2] - parabolic - tapers are weighted with a parabola in a decreasing manner.

method.name: info
method.description:
Print info about fl.multitaper~ to the max window for reference purposes. If no arguments are provided then all information is posted to the Max window. Else a set of flags is used to select which sections of the reference to display, and whether or not the information should be provided in a shortened form.
The following flags are available:
description - display the object description.inputs - display info on inputs.outputs - display info on outputs.io - display info on both inputs and outputs.parameters - display info on the object parameters.quick - display shorten versions of any info displayed.

attribute.name: rt
attribute.description:
Sets the realtime state for fl.multitaper~. When set to 0 fl.multitaper~ can form part of a non-realtime network for processing in message threads, using buffer~ objects for audio IO.
More info on non-realtime processing with FrameLib can be found in Tutorial 11.
